Topic.Title: Microsoft to launch WP8 reference design -- WITHOUT nvidia,

Message.Msg: "Microsoft reportedly is cooperating with chipset supplier QUALCOMM on development of Windows Phone 8 reference design aiming to attract more smartphone makers in China to enter production of WP8 phones for the entry-level and midrange smartphone segments in China and other emerging markets, according to industry sources. Microsoft is expected to release the WP8 reference design in mid-2013, with smartphone models built on the reference design to hit the market in the second half of the year, the sources indicated." Sounds like an excellent plan by the Microsoft/QUALCOMM Team. You know -- to capture the Enormous China cellphone market in 2013. A Very Very Good Plan.

Message.Title: U.S. Homeland Chief : Cyber 9/11 could happen "imminently"
Message.Msg: U.S. Homeland Chief : Cyber 9/11 could happen "imminently" Reuters – 15 hrs ago. WASHINGTON (Reuters) - Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano warned on Thursday that a major cyber attack is a looming threat and could have the same sort of impact as last year's Superstorm Sandy, which knocked out electricity in a large swathe of the Northeast. Napolitano said a "cyber 9/11" could happen "imminently" and that critical infrastructure - including water, electricity and gas - was very vulnerable to such a strike. "We shouldn't wait until there is a 9/11 in the cyber world. There are things we can and should be doing right now that, if not prevent, would mitigate the extent of damage," said Napolitano, speaking at the Wilson Center think tank in Washington and referring to the September 11, 2001, attacks. Napolitano runs the sprawling Homeland Security Department that was created 10 years ago in the aftermath of September 11 and charged with preventing another such event. She urged Congress to pass legislation governing cyber security so the government could share information with the private sector to prevent an attack on infrastructure, much of which is privately owned. A cyber security bill failed in Congress last year after business and privacy groups opposed it. The measure would have increased information-sharing between private companies and U.S. intelligence agencies and established voluntary standards for businesses that control power grids or water treatment plants. Business groups said the legislation was government overreach. Privacy groups feared it might lead to Internet eavesdropping. New cyber legislation is being considered, but it is unclear whether it will get through the gridlocked Congress. President Barack Obama is expected to soon issue an executive order that would set up a voluntary system to help protect some critical infrastructure and offer incentives to companies that participate. But without a new law, companies cannot be granted any kind of legal immunity for sharing information with the government and within the industry about potential threats. Officials have pointed to recent hacking attacks on U.S. banks as a sign that the cyber threat is real and growing. "The clarion call is here and we need to be dealing with this very urgently," said Napolitano. "Attacks are coming all the time. They are coming from different sources, they take different forms. But they are increasing in seriousness and sophistication." My my my. The U.S. Homeland Security Department is apparently concerned about "recent hacking attempts" by cyber-dreamer, mister ashraf.eassa "They are coming from different sources, they take different forms, and we need to be dealing with this very urgently," said Napolitano. As was suggested here last week by the Mayor of Bestville (pop. 719), the Feds need to put that ashraf.eassa guy on the B.S. Don't Fly List. Otherwise folks might wake up one morning and say, "What the Heck Happened to the value of my trading account?"

Message.Title: bears hearts are about to break..............................
what intel is doing with hpc, nvda dream on with omlette Denver
Message.Msg: google seekingAlpha and mlxn: During the September 11-13th Intel Developer Forum, Intel officially announced its intention to integrate its next-generation CPU with an interconnect device, theoretically cutting out the need for a third-party interconnect provider like Mellanox. Intel's intent was mentioned by multiple press sources and presentations from Intel's technical sessions on the topic are available online. By assembling interconnect technologies and engineering teams from Cray, QLogic, and Fulcrum, Intel should be well positioned to complete its task. But even if Intel doesn't meet its timeline goals, the chipmaker controls the CPU design, allowing it to build a design that only functions optimally with an Intel's interconnect. This integration could potentially provide power and performance synergies as well as cost savings for the end-users. It would also completely box Mellanox out of the high-end HPC (high-performance computing) market. Forget 'cheap' radios, you need interconnect to play the hpc game before long. And nvda ain't got no 'cheap' interconnect. Denver is best served as an omlette.

Topic.Title: what intel is doing with hpc, nvda dream on with omlette Denver

Message.Msg: So here's an idea for Intel's next-generation CPU. "The Intel Defender® CPU". It has a little pass-code, right? And when you try to connect something to it, it asks for the pass-code. So for example, if you connect a Genuine Intel Xeon Pro Graphics Accelerator, the next-generation Intel GPU asks, "Are you friend or foe?" And or course the Genuine Intel Xeon Pro Graphics Accelerator says, "I am a friend -- just from a different Intel profit center." And the next-generation Intel GPU says, "Okay then. You are my friend." But, if you try to connect one of those nvidia Tesla graphics cards, it says, "Hit the curb pal. You are not worthy of connecting." And the next-generation Intel GPU admisisters a one million volt cattle prod to the $2,500 nvidia Tesla graphics cards -- rendering it smoldering junk. Hence the name, "The Intel Defender® GPU".

Message.Title: Absolutely Nothing In The Tech Press About Nvidia
Message.Msg: I've been following Nvidia for 3+ years and I have never seen such a quiet period in the Tech Press about Nvidia. Frankly, I don't know what this means. At the Raymond James Tech conference Nvidia's presenter said before beginning his presentation; "I know when I talk about Gaming People's eye's will glaze over" and then proceeded to talk about Gaming and almost nothing about mobile. At CES Jensen appears to be doubling down on Gaming with the Project Shield and Nvidia Grid. Again nothing on mobile design wins. All the traders are breathlessly waiting for news about mobile, but nothing so far. Surely it will come...but trader and option players live for volatility....Too bad I say! I am of the camp that Nvidia's earnings and revenue will improve because of Nvidia's refocus on it's core Gaming. Mobile for Nvidia is looking like a back half 2013 and 2014 story. In the meantime I expect they will manage the mobile division on expenses and run the mobile division as a business I would be tickled pink if I could get $15-$16 for my shares in a year or so. In the meantime dividend is nice and the lack of volatility is even better. Of course Nvidia could actually be buying back shares to the tune of 100 million. But that is so out of character for Nvidia. Besides, most companies initiate buying back shares when the stock is high, not at a low. But Nvidia completely surprised me with the dividend so just perhaps they are buying shares down at these prices, and I won't have to wait a year or so for $15 to $16. Won't hurt my feelings at all if Jensen fools me again!

Topic.Title: Absolutely Nothing In The Tech Press About Nvidia

Message.Msg: I bought at $11.50 and came back only because Nvidia announced a dividend. Before when trading Nvidia you could play the "Tech Press" articles and swing trade reliably knowing that the hype would not live up to the billing, but your amount of sleep might be affected. Who will ever forget the run-up 2 years ago. New Product companies live by the buzz and die by not continuing to introduce more buzz and fall drastically when the buzz stops.....ala Apple! It just appears to me that Jensen has been chastised enough by the hype and buzz to just concentrate on making profits and growing the business steadily. IMHO, the pieces are in place for Nvidia to be a very reliable growth and income stock allowing one to buy for the long term...or at least the semiconductor cycle. If CNBC fast money boys start talking about Nvidia again.....then get ready to pull the trigger and get out. JMHO

Topic.Title: S&P closes above 1500 for the first time in five years...

Message.Msg: Per WSJ: S&P 500 Closes Above 1500 for First Time in Five Years The S&P 500 closed above 1500 for the first time in five years on Friday, capping its longest streak of daily gains since 2004. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index tacked on 8.14 points, or 0.5%, to 1502.96, its highest close since Dec. 10, 2007. The index rose for an eighth session in a row, the longest such streak since a nine-day run ended in November 2004. The Dow Jones Industrial Average advanced 70.65 points, or 0.5%, to 13895.98. The Nasdaq Composite Index gained 19.33 points, or 0.6%, to 3149.71.

Message.Title: Qualcomm job postings: 64-bit ARMv8 designers wanted
Message.Msg: Fudzilla: Qualcomm is advertising at least three software engineering positions that seem to indicate it is gearing up to enter the ARM server market. According to EE Times, the chipmaker is looking for designers who know their way around ARMv8-based server SoC ASICs and can deal with development, porting and integration of server platform management software and firmware. In plain English, Qualcomm is apparently working on 64-bit server SoCs. Although the company is the clear market leader in the ARM space, it never really focused on server parts. Other players, including AMD, Marvell, Samsung and Nvidia have also announced plans to enter the ARM server market. The first shipments of 64-bit server SoCs are expected next year, but Calxeda and Marvell are already shipping 32-bit SoCs for servers, but in limited numbers. ____ If the Q guys just started this, they may be playing catching up. as NVIDIA Project Boulder is well underway....

Message.Title: AAPL: "flash dump" closes stock at $439.88 - not the doing of retail investors or talk show
Message.Msg: SOURCE: Barrons Apple (AAPL) shares closed down $10.62, or 2.4%, at $439.88 this afternoon. ZeroHedge’s Tyler Durden points us to what appears to have been a “flash dump” in the closing moments of the market, noting a large block of $350 million worth of stock in the waning minutes of the session: Unlike traditional flash crashes where the trade is an HFT error, or a few shares traded through the entire bid or offer stack, in this case it looks like a very premeditated unloading of some 800K shares (some $350 million worth) of AAPL in the last second, with the full knowledge it was shake the market. Why anyone would want (or wait until the very last second) to do that, while covering the offsetting ES short in the pair trade, to ramp the market into the close, is anyone’s guess. .......
